Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I glanced at my phone, a message from my boyfriend lighting up the screen: “Let’s pick a night for our date! Any evening works for me.” I smiled, thinking about how we’d promised to spend more time together, to really be present. I wanted to make it special, to show him he mattered. But as I drove my taxi through the city, the meter ticking, I felt the familiar tug of responsibility. My evenings were when fares were best—steady rides, good tips, and, most importantly, fewer distractions on the road. I prided myself on being a careful driver, always following the rules, never rushing, even when the streets were clear and the temptation to speed up was strong. My boyfriend expected my time and attention, but my passengers expected a safe, reliable ride. I could feel the pressure building, the weight of wanting to be the perfect girlfriend and the responsible driver. My mind raced with possible compromises, but I couldn’t shake the feeling that no matter what I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
